comments.commentBody: What evidence do you have that Columbia erred in its' investigation?
I'm talking about the emails she sent BEFORE the alleged incident. Not after.

Are you not aware that assault is also a tort, handled in civil court? If you're an attorney and do not know this, that's sad.

I'm sure, then, that you support all organizations (private, public, non-profit) staying out of assault and harrassment claims, right? HR departments don't have the expertise to handle these matters, according to you, They must be addressed only in courts, right? So organizations should not have the authority to handle matters that their policies address?

I agree fully with Jonah Hill that we need to change the laws governing universities. They do not have the ability to properly investigate and adjudicate crimes. They should be required to cooperate with law enforcement and otherwise stay the hell out of it.

As for the questions asked of Ms Sulkowicz if you read the emails she sent to Nungesser you will understand why questions about certain kinds of sex were asked of her. Those emails appear to directly contradict her original statements.
Larry, Your comments are well-written and well-reasoned.  I always appreciate them.  Keep writing.

Greed, mostly, all $149m of it. Stupidity? Nah.

His mother might not have been wrong when she says that law enforcement would not hear of him again, should he be allowed to walk free. Why, he's learnt his lesson and will make certain that he'll cover all tracks. We won't hear of him again because we won't be able to find him, not because he won't offend again.

Really enjoyed this one. It seemed especially clean, clever, and non-quibbly. Loved "class in which students raise their hands" for ASL. And for once, an under-an-hour Saturday for me! (I'm really slow.)

What he did was what was inevitable. The authoritarians in our society like to believe that markets don't work, that a simple legal ban of something with a strong demand will stop trade.
What he ended up with was a truly free market with all of the things people are buying and selling anyway, just not as conveniently.
Yeah, and isn't it terrible that free individuals were able to buy and sell drugs to each other of their own volition? The horror!
Bad enough that Ulbricht created the site, but worse, that it was so successful.

Markets work. He simply provided a convenient place for trade that was going on to happen. It continues to go on, and will as long as market forces continue to work, no matter how draconian the laws you support become.
Sorry about that, perhaps you would prefer a planned economy with the government the only seller of products.

1. Debatable as to his involvement and, on a deeper level, how to distinguish this from Craigslist, where many illegal activities occur (and yet no one has prosecuted the owners of Craigslist).

2. Totally irrelevant in this case. Ulbricht was not charged or convicted of murder for hire. If that crime had been proven, I think the life sentence would be at least defensible - but it was not.

Dear Don,

I can only assume that you believe that the huge settlements made with respect to the mortgage misconduct and the LIBOR fraud and the money laundering by HSBC didn't buy get out of indictment deals. You must be buying ocean front property in Montana.
Cocaine and heroine are not akin to alcohol.

We learned that it's messy.
One opponent of justice is crime, and another one is naivity. And sometimes naivity is harder to fight.

"That such a group even exists is evidence we have become a nation of fools and idiots."

We have not. It is corruption, the corruption of our politics by money. Only such a group can get past the donor primaries. They act this way to get the money of narrow special interests and cranky old men, then the only ones running are this way.
Walker is biding his time until his true vocation is within reach; pool boy for Koch industries.

And in the realm of abortion politics, abusers.

It's beyond belief that Walker, who is destroying everything in his path, even thinks for a moment that he is presidential material.

After solving the abortion issue in Wisconsin, he is moving swiftly to defund public education at all levels. This man is a disaster and I hope he make the 10% baseline for Fox.

That Walker is as popular as he is, should give the great majority of us pause to wonder what it is that makes him so.

He is the antithesis to the idea that people actually think for themselves.
He is a petty demagog to those who are determined to impose their neolithic moral standards on anyone who does not agree with them. And, they seem to be multiplying like rabbits. Of course Walker and his ilk, do not have any proposals to help care for those children born to those mothers. He and his followers do not give a damn about the health of those women, or any women for that matter.

He will not get the GOP nomination, but just the idea he is considered a contender, gives me the willies. In my lifetime, I can not recall having seen and heard such a collection of venal, intrusive little men such as Walker, and his other GOP candidates.

That such a group even exists is evidence we have become a nation of fools and idiots.
This is no ordinary drug dealer. He is an Internet crime boss. As such, like any upper level Mafioso, he deserves his life sentence.
Only if they can prove that he screened to make sure all his clients were adult and of sound mind.  Or do libertarians believe we should legalize selling drugs to children?

Personal best time (18:43) for a Saturday despite starting off with BAD SMELL then KIDS' MENU at clue one. FLINTSTONE made me giggle. ACE AWARD was a guess as I don't follow the television biz, and never heard of DUXELLES before, since they don't have them at Denny's.

Last answer was STATE LINE...had a little trouble in that corner. Fun puzzle!

AJ - you're not in any position to determine what universities are equipped to handle.  Do you have some sort of expertise in this area?  Would you like university personnel to opine on how you're business should be conducted or whether you're equipped to handle an issue?
Yes. I have reviewed university disciplinary hearings as part of my job. It's frightening the way things are done.

Maybe your clients have the wrong person reviewing procedures if you don't know that assault is a tort?

You have supposedly reviewed such hearings, but you have no suggestions on how universities can handle this issue differently? If a another person in your firm assaults or harrasses you, that should only be left to the police to handle, correct? No one in your firm should handle the issue, right?
Universities can follow anti-discrimination law best by encouraging rape victims to seek legal remedies.
Is eBay largely concerned with the sales of drugs?

I think eBay does indeed have a responsibility to police their site as strictly as possible. Yes, some frauds will escape notice but EBay does have a responsibility to oversee the site and do everything they can to shut down criminals.  This man does not seem to have made any really reasonable attempt to police his site.

I suppose then the owners of eBay are responsible for all the fraud that goes on in their site. Countless fakes and frauds 24/7 and eBay does nothing but make money.

PS No one is above the law. There's joke.

Justice for society in this case seems clear to me: make some arrangement that would enable Mr. Ulbricht to use his considerable talents and abilities in rendering service to society. This guy went down the wrong path, but I believe he realizes it. He should be denied freedom for some period (not life, that's just gratuitous) and also any opportunity to profit monetarily from doing service, but to simply lock him away without affording opportunity to make some form of reparations for his actions is just a waste.

Okay Matt - just one question. Given that Backpage and Craiglist regularly promote and facilitate unlawful activities (prostitution, etc.) and, through ad revenue, directly profit from them, should the owners of Backpage and Craigslist also go away for life? How about bank executives who participate in money laundering? Cryptographers who create and profit from private communications networks that prevent government surveillance, thus facilitating illegal activity?

Give me a limiting principle here.

Matt,

There is a clear double standard here - there are corporations such as Dyncorp that are known to be involved in human trafficking (http://www.salon.com/2002/08/06/dyncorp/) and HSBC is laundering drug money (http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/feb/15/hsbc-has-form-mexic... with impunity. Do you think this government and the psychopaths that run it have any care for the plight of drug addicts? They don't. They simply want to eradicate their competition on behalf of their corporate buddies (which in a fascist model are one and the same) to maximize power and profit. This has been going on for a long time (see Opium Wars where HSBC was front and center) and it will take some real soul searching from true human beings to root this evil from our society.

This government and most others are run by the worst among us in concert with business interests that perfectly compliment them.

What is all this "he just created a marketplace" nonsense?  You can't just create and maintain a marketplace where anything goes and expect to somehow distance yourself from what happens.  In this case it was drugs, but what kind of sites do you think gun runners or human traffickers use to operate on a global scale [hint: it's not twitter]?  The man profited DIRECTLY from the transactions taking place and he shares criminal culpability in each and every one.  People keep calling it draconian as if this was all just a giant misunderstanding and he had no idea that he was the Pablo Escobar of the digital world.
Majority Catholic Countries? Like Sweden and Denmark?

Douthat alludes to the recent vote in Ireland in favor of marriage equality as "recent development" that he is hoping to "wade more fully into."  The problem he should wrestle with is "Why are the majority Catholic countries the most likely to embrace marriage equality?"

The criminal justice system is not the solution to drug addiction, but can be a useful component. Quite often the threat of incarceration is needed to get addicts to reach rock bottom and become committed to making real changes.

I think you mss the point. The alcohol and tobacco companies are paying a lot of time and money to keep their drugs the drugs of choice.  Did any of the executives of the tobacco companies get even a hand slap for lying to congress,  disclaiming any knowledge that their products were harmful or habit forming.  How many more lives have been ruined by alcohol ?  Yes, opium can kill you.  I'm hoping when i get old enough to die the same way the King of England did, with a drug overdose.  As far as drugs, you don't that PepsiCo and Coke don't know they make sugar water,  and fear to wake one morning one day and find consumers hold them in the same distain that they hold Monsanto?  And congress? Well, maybe not a low as congress, but still low.
You do realize he made at least $184 million from his youthful indiscretion.
Name me ONE other non-violent drug offender (he was not charged with any violent crime) with no criminal record who has received a life sentence.

No, I didn't view this kid as a Pablo Escobar type drug kingpin. I viewed him as a young adult with a brilliant mind that did have strong libertarian type beliefs.

Race neve entered my Mind.
Having read the comments to which you refer, with which I disagree, I think they do. Your making this into a race/class thing is silly.

Do the people on here who think the sentence is excessive think similar life sentences for "drug kingpins" from inner cities or extradited from Latin America  are also excessive?  Perhaps so, but, honestly, some of shock at this sentence seems to stem from the class and color of this particular defendant -- educated, middle class, white.
